user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarDelete_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarDelete_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32                              final_status;
    int                                status;
    OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t *impl;

    final_status = OS_SUCCESS;
    impl         = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_condvar_table, *token);

    status = pthread_cond_destroy(&impl->cv);
    if (status != 0)
    {
        final_status = OS_ERROR;
    }

    status = pthread_mutex_destroy(&impl->mut);
    if (status != 0)
    {
        final_status = OS_ERROR;
    }

    return final_status;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CondVarDelete_Impl:
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t OS_impl_condvar_table[OS_MAX_CONDVARS]
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t mut;
    pthread_cond_t  cv;
} OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No suspicious fragments found. OS_CondVarDelete_Impl does not call itself directly and contains only: (1) two calls to well-known POSIX library functions (pthread_cond_destroy and pthread_mutex_destroy) which are not application callbacks and do not call back into user-defined OS functions, and (2) a macro OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET that (per the provided additional code) resolves to direct table access/inline index extraction (OS_ObjectIndexFromToken returns token->obj_idx) and does not invoke functions that could recurse. The OS_impl_condvar_table is an array of plain records (no function pointers), and the struct contains only pthread types. There are no function pointers, callbacks, or other function calls in this fragment that could introduce indirect recursion back to OS_CondVarDelete_Impl, so no code fragments require further investigation for Rule 17.2.
